General.QuizName: Online Searches and the Filter Bubble
General.preQuizText: Answer the following questions based on Pariser’s TED talk.

Questions.questionText: Mark Zuckerberg’s comment motivated the speaker, Eli Pariser, to imagine a Web based on that definition of:
Pariser noticed that his Facebook page is different now because

answers.answerText:
He can only see comments
from people who already share his opinions.

Questions.questionText:
Google’s search produces different results depending on the person
searching?

Which of the following factors are used by Google to determine the
most appropriate results of a particular search:

answers.answerText: The geographic location of the person searching
The type of computer being used to conduct the search
The type of computer being used to conduct the search

Questions.questionText:
In the Google experiment that Pariser describes, there were only
minor differences between the search results of his two friends:

This trend toward “personalization” only applies to search engines
and social networks, and isn’t affecting the way we access news and information
through traditional sources, like newspapers.

Pariser thinks this tailoring of information — which he describes
as putting us inside our own personal “filter bubble” — is problematic because

answers.answerText: The Internet is showing us what we want to see, but not necessarily what we need to see

It will become very hard to access information that has not been tailored for them in some
way.
You don’t decide what gets inside your filter bubble, because that decision is determined invisibly and automatically by algorithms

You aren’t able
to see or know what has been excluded from your filter bubble.

Questions.questionText:
Pariser suggests we are presented with an unbalanced “diet” of
information because:

answers.answerText: Popular entertainment and sensational news are more profitable.
Somebody is intentionally trying to make society less informed and more divided.

We tend to make our
Internet decision based more on our impulses than on our desire to be “better”,
and algorithmic filters determine our preferences based largely on what we
click first.

Questions.questionText:
When Parisers says we are often surrounded by “information junk
food,” he is referring to:

answers.answerText:
Information, opinions, and
entertainment that are — just like junk food — convenient, easy, cheap,
filling, and immediately satisfying, but ultimately lacking in substance and
potentially unhealthy if consumed regularly and in large doses.

Questions.questionText:
When Pariser calls for today’s internet “gatekeepers” to “encode
that kind of responsibility into the code that they’re writing,” he’s asking for

answers.answerText:
Enough control to decide
what gets through personal filters and what doesn’t
